Name: VSimulators - Bath
Description:
Whether your research involves working in a high rise office building, exploring your newly designed structure, understanding human responses to changing environmental conditions or exploring people's physiological responses to the built environment, we can provide the multi-disciplinary capability to fully explore human-environment interactions.

VSimulators at Bath - Key Features:

- 3m x 4m self contained environment test chamber (supplied by Temperature Applied Sciences) which can be occupied by up to three occupants for extensive periods of time
- a custom designed motion platform, with freedom of movement in three directions (designed and developed by Servotest Systems, in collaboration with the University of Bath) (0.01Hz – 6HZ+, and amplitudes of up to +/- 400mm)
- projected 3D and 2D virtual reality (images are projected onto the walls), programmed to adjust the visual and audio sensory output according to the time of day and building height (designed and developed by Antycip Simulation, in collaboration with the University of Bath)
- motion tracking of occupants
- physiological recording of human factor responses


Environmental Control Features:
The VSimulator facility at the University of Bath offers precise environmental controls, as follows
- Air Temperature : 15 to 40 degrees centigrade
- Humidity : 20% to 80%
- Horizontal Illuminance : 50 to 2000 lux
- Colour Temperature : 2000 to 6500 K
- Lighting illuminance: 50-2000 Lux
- Radiant temperature: 5 – 40 degrees centigrade
Site Location: University of Bath, Claverton Down, Bath, BA2 7AY

Name: Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS) with Thermal desorption
Description: Utilised to characterise volatile organic compounds through gas chromatography separation, coupled to a single quadrupole mass spectrometer for nominal mass determinations. This instrument can analyse liquids, but also has a thermal desorption capability to analyse sorbent trapped VOCs and SVOCs, eg. for environmental sampling and air quality. Extensive spectral libraries (EI) eg. NIST. Can be used for identification purposes.

Name: Glove Box  - used in conjunction with other DReaM instruments
Description: Coupled to QTOF MS for MS analysis of air and/or moisture sensitive compounds in polar solvents. Can be used to set up air/moisture sensitive reactions for reaction monitoring by other DReaM equipment (NMR, MS, headspace MS, HPLC, UV)
Site Location: University of Bath, Claverton Down, Bath, BA2 7AY

Name: Headspace gas mass spectrometer (headspace gas MS)
Description: The headspace mass spectrometer samples from the headspace of a homogeneous reaction generating gases, using a carrier gas to flow through the headspace (typically argon). The mass spectrometer can be used to identify masses between 1 and 300 amu. Gases are not returned to the headspace after analysis.

Name: Confocal Laser Scanning Microscope Zeiss LSM-880 with Airyscan and multiphoton laser
Description:
Enviromentaly controled Confocal Microscope System with AiryScan Super-Resolution detector and InSight multiphoton IR-Laser.
Qualitative detection of fluorescently tagged proteins, cellular organels/compartments or chemical substances, and 3D reconstruction of the tagged structure in fixed specimens as well as in living cells, tissues or organisms. Co-localization studies of two or more fluorescently tagged proteins. Semi-quantitative and quantitative measurements of chemical processes, enzyme/protein kinetics in cells. Finds broad application in Biology, Medicine, Pharmacology, Physics, and Chemistry.

DMi8: Qualitative detection of fluorescently tagged proteins, cellular organels/compartments or chemical substances, in fixed specimens as well as in living cells, tissues or organisms. In combination with the hypoxic chamber, it provides immediate microscopic assesment in hypoxic/anoxic conditions. Finds broad application in Biology, Medicine, Pharmacology

Name: Flow Cytometer - BD FACSCanto II

Site Location: University of Bath, Claverton Down, Bath, BA2 7AY

Name: Flow Cytometer cell sorter - BD FACS Aria III
Description: Analysis of cell populations and subpopulations based on i) physical characteristics of the cells, and ii) specific tags that discrimate the different cell populations. FACS Aria III can discriminate up to 14 different fluorophores. Based on proper gating the instrument offers the ability to physically sort a heterogenous cell mixture in different sub-populations. Thus, collection of pure cell populations with specific characteristics is possible. It has broad application in Biology, Medicine, and Immunology both as a research and diagnostic tool.

Name: Ultra High Pressure Liquid Chromatography instrument (UPLC)  - used in conjunction with other DReaM instruments
Description: HPLC is used to separate the components in a homogeneous solution-phase mixture. Can be used to sample reaction mixtures directly from the reaction monitoring flow path for HPLC analysis (reaction mixure sampled is not returned to reaction vessel). This allows for separation of enantiomers to determine the enantiomeric excess over the course of a reaction, using a HPLC method and column established in advance by the user.
Site Location: University of Bath, Claverton Down, Bath, BA2 7AY

Name: UltraViolet-Visible spectrometer (UV-Vis) - used in conjunction with other DReaM instruments

Name: Walk-up Liquid Chromatography Electrospray quadrupole Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer (LC-ESI-QTOF MS)

It has mutliple chromatography columns configured to enable direct injection mode and C18 chromatography, depending on the user requirements. This system also has intact protein and peptide mapping capability with automated reproting function, and the software can be used for glycan analysis. The post-acquisition software, for in-depth sample investigation/annotation, is also available campus-wide.
